required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Carbidopa/Levodopa/Entacapone on Motor Function and Quality of Life in Patients With Parkinson's Disease
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Multi-center, Randomized, Open-label Study With Blinded Raters to Evaluate the Effects of Immediate Versus Delayed Switch to Carbidopa/Levodopa/Entacapone on Motor Function and Quality of Life in Patients With Parkinson's Disease With End-of-dose Wearing Off

brief_summary.textblock: To assess motor function and quality of life (QoL) in Parkinson's disease (PD) subjects with end-of-dose wearing off, comparing immediate and delayed switch to carbidopa/levodopa and entacapone.

detailed_description.textblock: This was a prospective, multi-center, randomized, open-label study with blinded raters to evaluate the effects of immediate versus delayed switch to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone on motor function and quality of life in patients with Parkinson's disease with end-of-dose wearing off.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to Week 4
primary_outcome.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5 point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Score From Baseline to Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: Quality of life was assessed with the Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Instrument (PDQUALIF), a 33-item self-reported questionnaire which includes seven domains: Social/role function, self-imaging/sexuality, sleep, outlook, physical function, independence, and urinary function. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 132. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Score From Baseline to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: Quality of life was assessed with the Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Instrument (PDQUALIF), a 33-item self-reported questionnaire which includes seven domains: Social/role function, self-imaging/sexuality, sleep, outlook, physical function, independence, and urinary function. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 132. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5-point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39) Total Score From Baseline to Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: The PDQ-39 is another instrument used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 156. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39) Total Score From Baseline to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: The PDQ-39 is another instrument used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 156. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of treatment (Week 16 in the Immediate Switch group, Week 20 in the Delayed Switch group)
secondary_outcome.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5 point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of treatment (Week 16 in the Immediate Switch group, Week 20 in the Delayed Switch group)
secondary_outcome.description: Quality of life was assessed with the Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Instrument (PDQUALIF), a 33-item self-reported questionnaire which includes seven domains: Social/role function, self-imaging/sexuality, sleep, outlook, physical function, independence, and urinary function. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 132. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39) Total Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of treatment (Week 16 in the Immediate Switch group, Week 20 in the Delayed Switch group)
secondary_outcome.description: The PDQ-39 is another instrument used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 156. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.

clinical_study.condition: Parkinson's Disease With End of Dose Wearing Off

arm_group.description: Patients were switched the day after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

Patients were switched 4 weeks after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

intervention.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Males or females 30-80 years of age (inclusive). Patients aged 81-85 years were eligible to participate if the principal investigator considered the patient to be in otherwise good health.
- Clinical diagnosis of Parkinson's disease exhibiting two of three symptoms (rigidity, resting tremor, bradykinesia).
- All patients were required to have end-of dose wearing off (EODWO, re-emergence of PD symptoms at the end of at least two daily doses of levodopa during waking hours).
- Taking regular doses of immediate release carbidopa/levodopa
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unstable Parkinson's Disease requiring booster doses or treatment with as needed dose regimens of levodopa
- Female subjects who are pregnant, trying to become pregnant or nursing an infant
Other protocol-defined inclusion/exclusion criteria applied to this study.

group.title: Immediate Switch
group.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched the day after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

group.title: Delayed Switch
group.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched 4 weeks after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

participants_list.participants: Not all subjects who completed the treatment phase chose to enter this optional extension phase.
Not all subjects who completed the treatment phase chose to enter this optional extension phase.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Change in Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to Week 4
outcome.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5 point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population: All randomized patients who received at least one dose of study drug and had at least one post-baseline assessment of the primary efficacy variable. Only patients with baseline and Week 4 UPDRS part III scores were included in the analysis.

The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched 4 weeks after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

measure.title: Change in the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39) Total Score From Baseline to Week 8
measure.description: The PDQ-39 is another instrument used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 156. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.
measure.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population: All randomized patients who received at least one dose of study drug and had at least one post-baseline assessment of the primary efficacy variable. Only patients with baseline and Week 8 PDQ-39 scores were included in the analysis.

outcome.title: Change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
outcome.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5 point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of treatment (Week 16 in the Immediate Switch group, Week 20 in the Delayed Switch group)
outcome.population: ITT population - For each patient, the last post-baseline measurement during the treatment phase was used as the end-of-treatment measurement. Only patients with baseline and end-of-treatment UPDRS part III scores were included in the analysis.

group.title: Immediate Switch
group.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched the day after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

group.title: Delayed Switch
group.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched 4 weeks after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

measure.title: Change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
measure.description: Motor function was assessed with the UPDRS part III. There are 14 items in the instrument, each measured on a 5 point scale (0-4): Speech, facial expression, tremor at rest, action tremor, rigidity, finger taps, hand movements, hand pronation and supination, leg agility, arising from chair, posture, gait, postural stability, and body bradykinesia. The sum of scores can range from 0 to 56; a higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.
measure.population: ITT population - For each patient, the last post-baseline measurement during the treatment phase was used as the end-of-treatment measurement. Only patients with baseline and end-of-treatment UPDRS part III scores were included in the analysis.

outcome.title: Change in Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Score From Baseline to End of Treatment
outcome.description: Quality of life was assessed with the Parkinson’s Disease Quality of Life Instrument (PDQUALIF), a 33-item self-reported questionnaire which includes seven domains: Social/role function, self-imaging/sexuality, sleep, outlook, physical function, independence, and urinary function. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The 1 to 5 range was recoded to 0 to 4 for the analysis. The total score can range from 0 to 132. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates improvement.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of treatment (Week 16 in the Immediate Switch group, Week 20 in the Delayed Switch group)
outcome.population: ITT population - For each patient, the last post-baseline measurement during the treatment phase was used as the end-of-treatment measurement. Only patients with baseline and end-of-treatment PDQUALIF scores were included in the analysis.

group.title: Immediate Switch
group.description: Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone was administered in 1 of 3 dose combinations: 12.5/50/200 mg, 25/100/200 mg, or 37.5/150/200 mg. The selected combination dose contained the same doses of carbidopa and levodopa the patient was receiving prior to switching to carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients were switched the day after randomization from combined carbidopa/levodopa to combined carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone. Patients received the same doses of carbidopa (12.5, 25.0, or 37.5 mg) and levodopa (50, 100, or 150 mg) they were receiving prior to the switch, combined with 200 mg of entacapone. The frequency of doses per day prior to the switch remained the same after the switch.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The terms and conditions of Novartis' agreements with its investigators may vary. However, Novartis does not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Any publications from a single-site are postponed until the publication of the pooled data (ie, data from all sites) in the clinical trial.
